hints.content: Start by understanding what an anagram is. An anagram is formed by rearranging the letters of a word. For example, 'listen' and 'silent' are anagrams.
Consider how to identify if two words are anagrams. One common method is to sort the characters of both words and compare the sorted results.
Think about how you can traverse the array of words. You need to check pairs of adjacent words to see if they are anagrams.
Remember that you can only delete a word if it has an anagram immediately before it. This means you should be cautious when iterating through the list.
You may want to use a loop to go through the words array. If you find anagrams, you can remove the second word in the pair and continue checking from the previous word.
Consider using a data structure that helps you keep track of the unique words you want to keep. A list or a set could be useful here.
When removing elements from the list, be aware that the indices will shift. You might need to adjust your loop to account for this.
Think about edge cases, such as when all words are unique or when all words are anagrams of each other. How would your logic handle these scenarios?
You can create a helper function to check for anagrams, which can simplify your main logic. This function could take two words and return a boolean.
Finally, after processing the list, ensure that you return the resultant list of words. Make sure to handle the return format as specified in the problem statement.

questionNotes: Each word has a length of 1 to 10.
Words consist of lowercase English letters.
You can only delete words at index i if words[i-1] and words[i] are anagrams.
The return format should be a list of strings.
